questions.question: In Asch's (1951) study on conformity, what effect did the presence of a dissenting confederate have on conformity rates?
questions.explanation: The presence of a dissenting confederate decreased conformity rates from 33% to 5.5%. This corresponds to: Decreased conformity to 5.5%.

questions.question: What is one explanation for resistance to social influence that involves the influence of others?
questions.explanation: Social support is an explanation for resistance to social influence, as it provides individuals with allies against conformity or obedience

questions.question: In Milgram's (1963) obedience study, how did the presence of disobedient peers affect obedience rates?
questions.explanation: The presence of disobedient peers reduced the percentage of participants who were fully obedient to just 10%. This corresponds to: Decreased obedience to 10%.

questions.question: According to the concept of locus of control, individuals with which type of locus are more likely to resist social influence?
questions.explanation: Individuals with an internal locus of control are more likely to resist social influence as they believe their actions are a result of their own abilities

questions.question: In a study by Hutchins and Este, what was found regarding individuals with a high internal locus of control?
options: They are more susceptible to social influence
They are less able to resist coercion
They are more able to resist coercion
questions.explanation: Hutchins and Este found that individuals with a high internal locus of control were more able to resist coercion in a simulated interrogation. This corresponds to: They are more able to resist coercion.

questions.question: What did Allen and Levine's study suggest about the importance of social support in resisting conformity?
options: It is only effective if the supporter is valid
It helps individuals resist even if the support is not valid
questions.explanation: Allen and Levine showed that social support helped people resist conformity even when the supporter was not particularly valid. This corresponds to: It helps individuals resist even if the support is not valid.

questions.question: What methodological limitation is associated with the concept of locus of control in resisting social influence?
options: It only applies to normative social influence
It is not applicable in real-world settings
It is too broad and vague
questions.explanation: Spector found that an internal locus of control was significant in resisting normative social influence but not in resisting informational social influence. This corresponds to: It only applies to normative social influence.

questions.question: How does the presence of social support impact an individual's ability to resist obedience according to Milgram's findings?
options: It only works in group settings
questions.explanation: Milgram suggested that the presence of disobedient confederates acted as role models, making it more likely that the real participant would also resist. This corresponds to: It decreases obedience.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of individuals with an external locus of control in relation to social influence?
options: They take personal responsibility for their actions
They feel more empowered to resist influence
They believe their actions are determined by external factors
They are less likely to conform
questions.explanation: Individuals with an external locus of control tend to accept that what happens to them is determined by external factors, making them more susceptible to social influence. This corresponds to: They believe their actions are determined by external factors.

questions.question: What role does breaking the unanimity of a group play in resisting conformity, as suggested by Asch's findings?
options: It has no effect on conformity
It makes it easier to resist conformity
It only works in large groups
questions.explanation: Breaking the unanimity of the group makes it easier for individuals to resist conformity, as shown by the significant drop in conformity rates when a dissenting confederate was present. This corresponds to: It makes it easier to resist conformity.
